description: From Spanish reata, from reatar (“to retie”). Compare lariat.

entries.meaning: (US, regional) A lariat or lasso. [from 19th c.]
examples: “You double-crossing devil,” the young man growled. “ […]  Hereafter you'll trot ahead of me at the end of a riata, while I keep you on the jump with a four-horse whip. Right now you're scattering my dunnage from hell to breakfast,  […] ”
